title: 108_hr3754
content: The Act is titled the "Fraudulent Online Identity Sanctions Act" and includes an amendment to the Trademark Act of 1946. The Trademark Act of 1946 is amended to include a new subsection (e) which establishes a rebuttable presumption of willful violation if false contact information is knowingly provided when registering a domain name used in connection with the violation. The Trademark Act of 1946 is amended to include a new subsection (e) establishing a rebuttable presumption of willful violation for providing false contact information when registering a domain name used in connection with the violation. Section 504(c) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include a rebuttable presumption of willful infringement if false contact information is knowingly provided when registering a domain name used in connection with the infringement. This does not limit what may be considered willful infringement under this subsection. The term 'domain name' is defined as in section 45 of the Act. The term 'name' is defined in section 45 of the Act 'An Act to provide for the registration and protection of trademarks used in commerce' approved in 1946. SEC. 4. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 18, UNITED STATES CODE. Amendment to Title 18, United States Code includes a sentencing enhancement for falsely registering a domain name and using it in a felony offense, doubling the maximum imprisonment or increasing it by 7 years. The terms "falsely registers" and "domain name" are defined in the amendment. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend sentencing guidelines to deter felony offenses carried out online using a domain name with false contact information. The Sentencing Commission will enhance sentences for felony offenses involving false contact information provided to domain name authorities. The "Trademark Act of 1946" was approved on July 5, 1946, under certain international conventions.
